Let’sKNOW Let’sKNOW! Wha t can you see in ? It is solid or liquid? Pic 1
! In , wha t is in the glass? Is it liquid or gas? Pic 2
! In , wha t is coming out of the pressur e cooker? Pic 3
States of Matter
Matter exists in three states- solid, liquid and gas. Matter is made up of tiny 
particles called molecules. The arrangemen t of molecules is different in each state.
1 2 3
Solid–  In solids, the molecules are tightly 
pack ed. They cannot move freely. So, solids 
have a fixed shape and volume. Example 
are– book s, tables, beds, buck ets and door s 
etc.We use different type of things in our daily life- book s, table, chair s, fans, bags, 
water and man y other s. Ther e is air around us, though we cannot see it. All 
these things occup y space and have weigh t. Anything that occupies space and 
has weigh t is called matter. StarterKnow About MatterUnit–VI : The World of Things
16
Environmental Studies-4119Molecules in solids

Liquid– In liquids, molecules are loosely pack ed. 
They can move to some distances. So, liquids 
have a fixed volume but do not have a fixed 
shape. They take the shape of the container in 
which they are kept. Water, milk, oil, cold drink 
are some examples of liquids.
Gases–  In gases, molecules are very loosely 
pack ed. They can move freely in all directions. 
So, gases do not have a fixed volume or shape. 
They take the volume and the shape of the 
container . The molecules of the gas spread out 
to take up all the available space. 
Change of State
Matter exists in more than one state. water can exist in all three For example– 
states– solid, liquid and gas. Matter can be chang ed from one state to another by 
heating or cooling. 
! Solid to liquid– When we heat a solid, it chang es into a liquid. For example, ice 
(solid) chang es into water (liquid) on heating. This process is called melting.
! Liquid to gas– When we heat a liquid, it chang es into a gas. For example, 
water(liquid) chang es into water vapour (gas) on heating. This process is 
called evapor ation.
! Gas to liquid–  When we cool a gas, it chang es into a liquid. For example, water 
vapour (gas) chang es into water(liquid) on cooling. This process is called 
condensa tion.
! Liquid to solid–  When we cool a liquid, it chang es into a solid. For example, 
water (liquid) chang es into ice(solid) on cooling. This process is called 
freezing.
Environmental Studies-4 120Molecules in liquids
Molecules in gases

Soluble and Insoluble Substances
Substances such as salt and sugar dissolv e in water. They are called soluble 
substances . Substances such as wood, sand and chalk do not dissolv e in water. 
They are called insoluble substances . A solid that dissolv es in a liquid is called 
solut e. A liquid in which the solut e dissolv es is c ause a solvent. The liquid w e get 
when a solut e dissolv es in a solvent is called solution .
Solut e + Solvent  Solution
Sugar + Water Sugar Solution
Take a glass of water. Add one teaspoon of salt in it. Stir it well what do you 
see? 
You will not be able to see the salt. Taste the water. It tastes salty. Why?
Because, salt has dissolved in water. 
Conclusion – Salt is soluble in water. ActivityActivity
Miscible and Immiscible Liquid
Activity–  Take a glass half filled with water. Now at some milk into it. Stir well. The 
two liquids mix together and appear as one liquid. We say that these two liquids 
have dissolv ed in each other . The liquids which dissolv e in each other are called 
miscible liquids. Water is c alled a universal solven t bec ause it c an dissolve a 
wide variety o f substanc es.You  Know Must (Knowledge )Water Adding Salt Salt solution
Environmental Studies-4121Salt

Now, take another glass half filled with water and add 1 teaspoon of some oil in it. 
Stir well. You will see that oil forms a separ ate layer on top. This shows that these 
two liquid do not dissolv e in each other . The liquids which do not dissolv e in each 
other are called immiscible liquids. 
Permanent and T emporary Changes
Permanen t chang es are the chang es which remain for a long er time. They are not 
reversible.  When we are grown we can't chang e back into a baby. For example–
Thus, growth is a permanen t chang e. 
Some more examples of permanen t chang es are–
! Milk changing into curd.
! Cooking of rice.
! Burning of coal.
! A baby plan t growing into a tree. 
Tempor ary chang es are the chang es which are there only for a short period of 
time. Tempor ary chang es are reversible. For example-  Water turning into ice is Water Adding milk Miscible liquids
Water Adding oil Immiscible liquids
Environmental Studies-4 122
Milk
oil

called a tempor ary chang e because on melting it we can get water again.
Some more examples of tempor ary chang es are–
!  Stretching of a spring.
! Folding of a paper shee t.
! Squee zing of a rubber ball.
! Dissolving sugar into water.

We need to measur e a lot of things in our day- to- day life. We measur e 
leng th, distance, weigh t, time, etc. Some common measur emen t that we see 
around us are—
Ÿ A vegetable vendor weighs  the vegetables which one buys.
Ÿ A tailor stitches our clothes according to our measur emen t.
Ÿ A cloth merchan t measur es the leng th of each piece of cloth which we 
buy.a tailor measuring leng th
of a bo y's jeans.a grocer w eighing v egetable
with a beam balance
Measurement
Measur emen t is a system to measur e the  heigh t, weigh t, capacity , etc. It is done by 
comparing an unkno wn quan tity with a known quan tity. This known quan tity is 
Environmental Studies-4127

Measurement of Length
Leng th tells us how long or how tall a thing is. Earlier , people used their body parts 
to measur e leng th. Hand span, cubit and foot span are some units used at that 
time. But, these are non- standar d units and the measur emen t done using body 
parts varies from person to person.
For example— The leng th measur ed using your foot span will be different from 
your father's footspan.called the standar d unit.
In this chap ter, we will study about the measur emen t of leng th, mass and time. 
Hand span Cubit Foot span
Now a days, standar d units are used to measur e leng th. The standar d unit of leng th 
is metre (m). Smaller leng ths are measur ed in centime tres (cm) or millime tres 
(mm). Larger leng ths are measur ed in kilome tres(km).
Leng th is measur ed by using ruler , metre rod or measuring tape. 
The units of leng th are related to one another .
 10 millime tres = 1 centime tre
 100 centime tres = 1 metre
 1000 metres = 1 kilome tre  
Ruler Rod Tape
Environmental Studies-4 128

Precautions to be taken while using a ruler—
 1. Ruler should be placed very close to the object along its leng th.
 2. Eye should be kept exactly above the poin t wher e the measur emen t is 
to be taken.
 3. Avoid taking readings from the zero mark of the ruler if its edges are 
broken.
Measurement of Mass
Mass is the measur emen t of how heavy or light a thing is. Different things have 
different masses. Mass is measur ed in terms of the weigh t of the things. Weigh t of 
lighter things is measur ed in gram (g) or milligr am (mg). Weigh t of heavier things is 
measur ed in kilogr ams (kg).
Weigh t is measur ed by using a beam balance or an electr onic balance. Measur e the length of your EVS book 
using a ruler and write the answer in 
the blanks space.ActivityActivity
My EVS book is ______________
cm long.
Units of mass are related to one another
 100 milligr ams = 1 gram
 1000 grams = 1 kilogr am Beam balance Electr onic balance
Environmental Studies-4129

Go to the mark et with your mother to buy some vegetables. 
Observe, how does the grocer weigh the vegetables. What does 
he have to weigh different quantities of vegetables ?ActivityActivity
Measurement of Time
Time is the measur e of the interval 
between two events,  Time is 
measur ed in units called seconds(sec.), 
minut es(min) and hour s(hr).
Watches and clocks are used to 
measur e time.Wrist watch Wall clock
Units of time are related to one another as—
 60 seconds = 1 minut e
 60 minut es =  1 hour
How to see time in an analogue clock–
 1.  Look at the number s on the clock face.
 2. Locate the short er hand, which tells you the hour .
 3. Locate the long er hand, which tells you the minut es.
 4. Now, read the time.  
Digital clock
a digit al clock is an alterna tive to a traditional 
analogue clock. This type of clock shows 
number s to displa y the time in a digit al forma t. 
Analogue w atch
Environmental Studies-4 130

ŸHand-Span – The maximum distance between the tips of the thumb and 
the little finger.
ŸCubit   – Distance from the elbo w to the tip of the middle finger.
ŸFoot-Span – The distance between the tip of the toe and the heel of the 
foot.

Let’sKNOW Let’sKNOW
Knowing the sides— A very simple way of locating a 
place is by knowing the side on which it is situa ted. 
When we give directions to a place in gener al manner , 
we use the four sides in relation to our body . The side 
we face is our front, the side behind us is our back, the 
side towards our right hand is the right hand side and 
the side towards our left hand is the left hand side.
Directions— There are four main 
directions east, west, north and south.  If 
we stand facing the rising sun, the east is 
in front of us. West is at our back, the left 
hand poin ts towards the north and the 
right hand poin ts towards the south.
Land mark s— Landmark s are import ant poin ts or places of reference which help 
us to locate a place wher e we have to reach. A cinema hall, hospit al, school, 
temple, mark et or even a pole or tree are some landmark s which can be easily 
iden tified in a locality.
Sketches— A sketch is rough drawing of a place which help s us to locate our 
destination. It does not show the exact distance of one place in relation to another 
place.
Map s—A map is a flat drawing of place . Unlik e a sketch, a map shows directions. A 
map contains signs, symbols and a scale to locate the place shown on it.
Directions, landmark s, sketches, map s etc. help us to locate a place wher e 
we have to reach. They guide our movemen ts better and reduce the time 
and efforts requir ed to reach our destination. They also prevent us from 
getting lost.
Environmental Studies-4 136

Colour s– On a map different colour s are used to represen t different land forms and 
water bodies. Some of them are–
 1. Blue colour — river, oceans, seas etc
 2. Yellow colour — deserts
 3. Green colour — plains
 4. Brown colour — moun tains
 5. Red colour  — plateau
 6. Whit e colour — snow
Signs and Symbols–  Signs and symbols are used to show features like rivers, roads, 
temples, bridg es, dams, railways etc on a map.
 Some of them are–
 Railw ay       Bridg e
 Gurudw ars      Dam
 Temple       Forest
 Chur ch       Post office
 Mosque       Police station
 Metalled Road     Unme talled road
Scale of map–  A map is much smaller than the area shown by it. So a scale has to be 
used to draw a map. A scale uses a small unit of measur emen t which is equal to 
much bigger unit.
For example – if 1 cm = 100 km,
On the map, the distance between two places A and B is 2 cm. Then, they are 200 
km away from each other , on the ground. A scale is always given in a corner of the 
map. A book containing different map s is called an Atlas.
Direction on the map–  The t op side of the map alw ays sho ws north, bot tom side 
shows south, left hand side shows west and the right hand side shows east. All the 
map s contain this pattern of direction.Features of a Map
Environmental Studies-4137

You  Know Must (Knowledge )
! Destination – The place wher e we have to reach.
! Metalled Road – Roads made up of cemen t, concr ete and coal tar.
! Unme talled Roads – Roads made up of mud and gravel (gener ally 
found in rural areas).
! Legend – The explana tion of colour s, sign and symbols in a 
map.Legend or key– A legend or key tells us wha t the 
colours and the symbols used in the map 
represen t. It is usually given in a small box in the 
corner of the map.
How to draw a map–  To draw the map of a place, we need to keep the landmark s of 
that place in mind. Now, first take a centre poin t. Then go right from it and keep 
drawing the landmark s you find. Similarly go up, down and left. Use symbols to 
show each place that you see. Then draw a legend to explain the symbols you have 
used in your map.
We should learn how to read a map as it is an import ant skill. It help s us to find our 
way and to stay safe.
The art of making maps is called cartogr aphy and the people who mak e 
maps are called cartogr aphers.
Key termsKey termsKey termsYou  Know Must (Knowledge )
Nowa days people use digital maps and can shar e their exact location 
through their devices.
Environmental Studies-4 138
